Simulate temperature shift scenarios from a fitted seasonal curve

Source: R/simulate_temp_shifts.R
simulate_temp_shifts.Rd

Given the output of fit_seasonal_temp(), generate temperature scenarios by adding fixed deltas (e.g., +1°C to +5°C) to the fitted daily mean cycle.

Usage

simulate_temp_shifts(
  fit,
  deltas = 1:5,
  model = "best",
  dates = NULL,
  as_long = TRUE
)

Arguments

fit

A result list from fit_seasonal_temp().

deltas

Numeric vector of °C increments to add (default 1:5).

model

Which fitted model to use. Use "best" (default; lowest AIC) or a specific model name present in fit$metrics$model (e.g., "sin1").

dates

Optional Date vector. If supplied, the fitted day-of-year curve is mapped to these dates (using lubridate::yday); otherwise the native day_of_year from fit$daily_avg (1–365) is used.

as_long

Logical; if TRUE (default) return long format with columns key (scenario label) and temp_c. If FALSE, return wide columns baseline, Temp+1C, Temp+2C, ...

Value

A tibble with either day_of_year (no dates) or date (if provided), plus simulated temperatures across scenarios.

Examples

data(weather_nl)
fit <- fit_seasonal_temp(weather_nl, funcs = c("sin1","sin2"))
sims <- simulate_temp_shifts(fit, deltas = 1:5)      # long format over DOY
head(sims)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 3
#>   day_of_year key      temp_c
#>         <dbl> <fct>     <dbl>
#> 1           1 baseline -1.16 
#> 2           1 Temp+1C  -0.159
#> 3           1 Temp+2C   0.841
#> 4           1 Temp+3C   1.84 
#> 5           1 Temp+4C   2.84 
#> 6           1 Temp+5C   3.84 

# Map to actual dates:
days <- seq(as.Date("2024-01-01"), as.Date("2024-12-31"), by = "day")
sims_dates <- simulate_temp_shifts(fit, deltas = c(1, 3, 5), dates = days, model = "best")
head(sims_dates)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 3
#>   date       key      temp_c
#>   <date>     <fct>     <dbl>
#> 1 2024-01-01 baseline -1.16 
#> 2 2024-01-01 Temp+1C  -0.159
#> 3 2024-01-01 Temp+3C   1.84 
#> 4 2024-01-01 Temp+5C   3.84 
#> 5 2024-01-02 baseline -1.29 
#> 6 2024-01-02 Temp+1C  -0.287
